title: SB 354
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 7522.02 of the Government Code in California is amended. Section 7522.02 of the Government Code in California, effective January 1, 2013, applies to all state and local public retirement systems and participating employers, including various specific systems and individual retirement plans. Compliance with the Internal Revenue Code and California Constitution is required for administration. The California Government Code Section 7522.02, effective January 1, 2013, applies to all state and local public retirement systems and participating employers. However, there are exceptions for certain entities and public employees protected under federal law until a specific date or court ruling. The California Government Code Section 7522.02, effective January 1, 2013, applies to all state and local public retirement systems and participating employers. Exceptions include public employees protected under federal law until a specific date or court ruling. The benefit plan required by this article applies to new public employees as defined in Section 7522.04. The benefit plan under California Government Code Section 7522.02 applies to new public employees. Those who were employed by a public employer before January 1, 2013, and then by a subsequent public employer after that date, will be subject to the retirement plan of the subsequent employer if certain conditions are met. An individual employed before January 1, 2013, who changes positions without a break in employment and joins a different defined benefit plan in another public retirement system will be subject to the new plan as if they were hired before December 31, 2012. If a public employer offers a defined benefit pension plan with a lower cost formula before January 1, 2013, they can continue with that formula. If they adopt a new formula after January 1, 2013, it must be approved by the retirement system's chief actuary, retirement board, and the Legislature. New members must only participate in the new formula. The defined benefit formula for new members must be approved by the retirement system's chief actuary, retirement board, and the Legislature. New members can only participate in the lower cost formula in place before January 1, 2013, or a formula that meets the requirements of this article and is approved by the Legislature. If a public employer offers a retirement benefit plan consisting solely of a defined contribution plan before January 1, 2013, they may continue to do so. However, if they adopt a new defined benefit pension plan or formula after January 1, 2013, it must meet the requirements of this article, be certified by the retirement system's chief actuary and board, have no greater risk or cost to the employer than the required formula, and be approved by the Legislature. New members can only join the existing defined contribution plan or a plan that complies with the article's requirements. New members of the employer's plan may only participate in a defined contribution plan that was in place before January 1, 2013, or a plan that conforms to the requirements of this article. Employers can offer a defined contribution plan on or after January 1, 2013, with or without a defined benefit plan, regardless of previous offerings. If the Cities of Brea and Fullerton form a joint powers authority after January 1, 2013, they may offer employees the same defined benefit plan they had before joining the authority. This applies to employees from the City of Brea, City of Fullerton, or other specified cities who are not new members and are hired by the joint powers authority within 180 days of the common power being exercised. On or before January 1, 2017, a city in Orange County contiguous to Brea or Fullerton may join a joint powers authority, with a limit of three cities. New members joining after January 1, 2013, must adhere to defined benefit plan requirements. Judges' Retirement Systems are exempt from certain benefit and compensation limitations. On or before January 1, 2017, a city in Orange County contiguous to Brea or Fullerton may join a joint powers authority, with a limit of three cities. New members joining after January 1, 2013, must adhere to defined benefit plan requirements. Judges' Retirement Systems are exempt from certain benefit and compensation limitations. The Judges’ Retirement System and the Judges’ Retirement System II are not required to adopt specific defined benefit formulas or compensation limitations. This article does not provide membership in any public retirement system for individuals ineligible under the system's rules or laws. Public retirement systems must modify their plans to comply with the requirements of this article by January 1, 2013.
